titleInfo.title: Letter from Margaret Croft to Elise Croft from Rabun Gap

mods.abstract: Letter written from Margaret to Elise from Rabun Gap, Georgia. She replies to a recent letter from Elise, expresses her shock about "the unbelievable horror closing in on us" and "a part of us that has disappeared just as completely and irrevocably as our life in Habana [sic]." She refers to "man-made machines devastating the divine beauty of God's creation," which may refer to damages done to Grassmere property and crops by construction at the Radnor railyards. She also discusses her health and Rabun Gap news.

Margaret Croft took an interest in the Southern arts and crafts movement sometime after moving back to Tennessee from Cuba, and learned to weave at the Hambidge Center in Rabun Gap, Georgia. She also struck up a friendship with Mary Crovatt Hambidge, regularly corresponding with her and visiting Rabun Gap at least once a year.
